nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction improves machine learning performance and efficiency for hyperspectral optical imaging regression tasks such as soil moisture estimation
Hyperspectral optical imaging produces high-dimensional, strongly correlated spectral data that create computational and generalization challenges for ML models
Principal Component Analysis (PCA) can reduce dimensionality by transforming correlated spectral bands into uncorrelated components ordered by explained variance
A Random Forest regression trained on PCA-transformed hyperspectral features can provide strong predictive performance for soil moisture
The study used a hyperspectral dataset of 679 samples acquired with a Cubert UHD 285 camera across 125 spectral bands (450-950 nm) with reference soil moisture values from a TRIME-PICO sensor
Data preparation standardized spectral features using StandardScaler, split data with test size 0.3 and fixed random state 42, and inspected soil moisture distribution for reproducibility
Number of principal components was chosen to retain >99 percent cumulative variance based on covariance matrix, eigenvalue distribution, and a scree plot
RandomForestRegressor configured with 100 trees, test size 0.3, random state 42, and R2 as performance metric was used to evaluate predictive performance on PCA-transformed features
Correlation analysis of selected bands showed strong interband correlations (e.g., near 642 nm and 742 nm), indicating redundancy amenable to dimensionality reduction
Dataset distribution: soil moisture ranged approximately 25 to 43 percent, centered around 32 percent, providing a moderately narrow regression target distribution
PCA projected the 125-band data onto principal components; the first two components explained over 99 percent cumulative variance (PC1=0.9889, PC2=0.0064)
Scree plot and eigenvalue drop after PC2 validated that components beyond PC2 contributed negligible variance and could be excluded
Projection onto PC1 and PC2 produced clearer separation/clustering of samples by soil moisture compared to higher-dimensional space, improving visualization and interpretability
The Random Forest trained on PCA-reduced two-component features achieved R2 = 0.947, explaining approximately 94.7 percent of soil moisture variance

Conclusion: PCA reduced redundancy and computational complexity while preserving strong predictive accuracy, supporting PCA as an effective baseline dimensionality reduction for hyperspectral regression
Limitation and future work: results are based on a single dataset and linear PCA; alternative feature extraction methods and validation across diverse sensors and scenarios should be evaluated
